div.p:
1. VI:30.Mr Ironside called this morning with papers to be sent to T. Newton, Chairman of the Committee of Commerce— General Van-Ness came, and I had further explanations with him, upon the demand of Kerr against me. He said that Mr Kerr’s feelings were prodigiously hurt at the imputations of fraud that I had cast upon him; and that Thomas and M’Intyre, who were present on the 20th of March, both concurred with him Van Ness that I did more than once use the term fraud— I said if I had used it, my meaning referred to that which had been practised upon me— I had not meant to charge fraud personally upon Kerr— I had charged him with unfairness, in taking advantage of my interposition to save a perishing family
from a Distress for 125 dollars to make me charge myself for a further payment of half as much more— This combined with what I believed to be the woman’s misrepresentations, had produced on me the effect of fraud— But I had distinctly told Kerr, that having had no direct intercourse in the transaction, either with him, or with Mrs Moulton, I did not know that he had practised deception in the case— Van Ness told me of several proposals that he had made to Kerr, none of which he agreed to short of that of my paying the whole Note. But he said Kerr offered to give me an order for the Rent, so that I might distrain for it as he had done, and even to give me an order for a quarter subsequent to the date of the Note— He commenced an argument to me, that perhaps the note might be recoverable at Law or in a Court of Equity, though drawn by a married woman, and reminded me of the usual maxim that a man must consider before he signs his name, what the consequences may be— I told him I had no doubt, Lawyers might make a seven years question of it in judicial Courts in which each of the parties might spend seven times the amount of the Note, and finally leave Mr Kerr where he was at the beginning— I was convinced he could not recover the Note, either at Law or in equity— But my name was upon the note, and therefore I would pay it, and take care to have no possibly avoidable transaction with Mr Kerr thereafter. I would consider of his last proposal, and take measures to obtain such security as might be practicable from Moulton; not however by distress; and would then let him know the result— He endeavoured to throw all the blame of the transaction upon Mrs Moulton, who he said had found upon enquiry to be a woman of bad character, and was implicated in some of the transactions of an Attorney named Levi Burr, suspended from practice last Summer, for malpractices— At the Office Mr Savage brought his Letter containing the argument for the appointment of him as Consul and Agent at Guatimala— Mr Rice of Boston a claimant upon the Haytian Government, came to enquire when the promised Instructions to Commodore Porter would be sent— As soon as I could prepare them— I told MrRice, my impressions that this new effort would prove as fruitless as all the rest, for which I gave him my reasons and in which he fully concurred— Dr Watkins came to ask a loan of money in advance of his Salary to the close of the Florida Treaty claim Commission which will be on the 8th. of next June— He stated his extreme distress and the necessity under which he had been to anticipate his Salary to this time. I told him I would in a few days comply with his request. E. Wyer came
and passed half an hour at the Office— Evening dancing party at General Brown’s, which I attended with Mary Hellen and Abigail Adams— John did not go— Took Blunt to his lodgings at Gadsby’s.— Mrs Adams still keeps her chamber, and was more unwell than yesterday.

div.p:
2. VII.W. Plumer this morning brought me a pamphlet sent me by its author Jacob B. Moore— Annals of the town of Concord in New Hampshire— Plumer spoke also of a recent conversation between him and Mr Van Buren, who was sounding him with a view to bring him over to Mr Crawford’s interest— Van Buren acknowledged himself under personal obligations to me, but said he had supported Crawford as the Republican candidate. That enquiries had been made last Summer in the Albany Argus, whether I was willing to be considered as the Republican Candidate; and answered not satisfactorily in the New-York American— While Plumer was there Mr Conway of Arkansas came and introduced General Rector, of Missouri— A Mr Walker of Pennsylvania, appointed Consul at Glasgow in the place of Harvey Strong came for his Commission, and for a Letter of advice to Strong informing him of his removal— I walked with Plumer to the Capitol, to hear the close of Mr Webster’s speech upon the Tariff, which I did. He spoke about an hour, but the principal part of his Speech was delivered yesterday. It was universally admitted to be an able and powerful speech. Many of the members came and spoke to me while I was in the house. Tomlinson of Connecticut, and Van Rensselaer of New-York (Albany) spoke of Accounts received by them from their respective States, containing manifestations of opinion against Mr Crawford who is now denominated the Caucus Candidate— J. W. Taylor told me that J. A. Dix had been with him this morning from General Brown who was extremely anxious himself to see Taylor. The object was to state to Taylor, that it was the desire of Mr Calhoun to be supported for the Office of Vice President— That there was every prospect of a certainty that there would be a majority of the Legislature of New-York for me: that the wish of Mr Calhoun’s friends was to fall in with this prospect, and they wished that this arrangement might be further recommended from this place. Taylor said he believed the best way would be to let the thing take its course— I said that my friends would do as they should think proper— Personally, and on purely public grounds, I should prefer to see the Vice-Presidency conferred upon General Jackson— I believed—the public sentiment among those really my friends was decidedly, perhaps unalterably the same. The only possible reason for hesitation was Jackson’s being a Candidate for the first Office. And for that reason I thought the course of New-York should be left to itself— I had no objection to Mr. Calhoun’s obtaining the Vice-President— C. A. Foote gave
me a small coloured drawing directed to Mrs Adams, sent as he said by his eldest Sister, a widow Brian; an emblem of Friendship— He said his Sister and his father were both great Adamsites, though he himself was a Caucus man— I told him laughing that his Sister was a wiser politician than he; which he said was very possible— Crowninshield, after Webster had finished his speech, had some conversation with him in his seat, and immediately afterwards came to me and enquired if I had expressed an opinion in favour of the present Tariff-Bill—I said no—not as it stood— The double duty upon Molasses was to me an insuperable objection against it— He said, he had just been talking with Webster, and asked him, how came on with him Presidential Affairs; to which he answered he did not know, and to tell him the truth did not care— Why so?—Why it seemed to him, nothing was to be got with one more than with another— There was this damn’d Tariff—and our friend J. Q. is as bad upon it as any of the rest— No, said Crowninshield; I have understood he was not in favour of this Bill— “I had it (said Webster) from his own lips”— While Crowninshield was telling me this, Webster came out from his seat, and was passing by us— I called to him, and he sat down by me. I asked him, if he had said I had told him I was in favour of this Tariff-bill as it now stood— He said no— I had had no Conversation with him on the subject— But he had been told last week, that upon some enquiry made of me, I had answered I was in favour of the Bill— Crowninshield had not expected I should so immediately call upon Webster, for explanation; and Webster expected it as little— They were both embarrassed— Crowninshield said he had understood Webster to have said he had my opinion directly from myself, which Webster again explicitly disavowed— When he was gone, Mr Crowninshield told me that Webster had expressly said in words what he had repeated to me— It was impossible that he should have misunderstood him, and added he had not a doubt that Webster had positively engaged to support Calhoun for the Presidency; and was now ready to support any one else.— At all Events this incident completes the demonstration of Webster’s political feelings towards me— Calhoun and Crawford have both taken hold of his Ambition, and he has fallen into their toils— While I was at the House my Messenger came there and summoned me to the Presidents, where I found a cabinet-meeting assembled— They had already been two hours or more in Session, and all the members but myself were present— Mr Crawford for the first time since last Summer— The meeting had been suddenly called, and the subject was a claim of the State of Virginia, for Interest, which she had paid upon monies, borrowed during the late War, to pay for the defence of the State— Militia Services—for which the United States have already paid the claim of the State; but this was for Interest, on monies borrowed by the State at the time— The question had been much discussed before I came in—Mr Crawford earnestly in favour of making the allowance—Mr Wirt warmly pressing for it—Mr Calhoun, very faintly opposing it, and Mr Southard silent. The president read several Letters from him as Secretary of War, to the Governor of Virginia in August & September
of the year 1814. warning him to be ready to repel an attack of the Enemy upon Norfolk, or Richmond— This was the authority upon which the Militia had been called out, and the expenses incurred— I enquired for a Law by which they were authorised, but was referred only to that of 10. April 1812. which gave no such authority— It was observed that the claim for payment of the militia had already been allowed and paid; but I observed the authority for the expenditure was questionable as much upon a demand for interest, as for principal— Every precedent and rule for the Settlement of Accounts at the War and Treasury Departments was against this allowance and its admission would have absorbed about a Million of public money at once; besides establishing a precedent which would swallow hundreds of Millions in future— There were two cases of interest allowed upon payments of this description made by States. They were Pennsylvania and New-Jersey; but in both it was in fulfilment of express previous engagements— I thought the general rule and established practice at the Treasury of not allowing interest wise and just; and if it should once be broken in upon in favour of a State, I could discern no principle upon which it could be denied to individuals— The rule was just because the demand for interest always rested upon grounds distinct from that of the debt upon which it was claimed— The right to interest was impaired by numberless contingencies, which did not affect the principal— It was so considered by all Nations. It had been so considered in our Relations, both foreign and Domestic, besides being the foundation of the established Treasury rule. And I instanced the withholding of interest during the period of the revolutionary War, upon British debts recovered in this Country after the War— A Subject which had been long in controversy between the two Nations, and was ultimately settled by a compromise. Also our own funding system, in which all the arrears of Interest had been funded at an interest of 3. per Cent, and now constituted the Stock of that denomination, while all the capital of the debt had been funded at 6 per Cent interest, though upon one third of it the payment of interest was deferred for ten years. Crawford denied that the 3. per Cent Stock had been constituted from arrears of Interest— He had once at a former meeting made the same denial and I had suffered it to pass without reply— I now merely read the 5th. Section of the Act of 4. August 1790. making provision for the debt of the United States.— I said if any thing was to be done upon this claim of Virginia, by the Executive, I thought it should only be to refer it to Congress, and that without any recommendation of it— I should prefer
leaving it to the Representation from Virginia to bring it into Congress themselves— Crawford said if it was not allowed by the Executive he should also prefer leaving it to Congress themselves; for if they should make the allowance he was afraid they would extend it also to individuals, to which he was not disposed to assent— Calhoun and Southard now spoke decidedly against the allowance, and it was concluded that the answer should be accordingly— It was remarked that Governor Barbour had already brought the subject before the Senate, where it had been rejected or strongly discountenanced— Southard said this was an additional reason for the Executive to decline making the allowance, which Crawford admitted, saying he did not know it had been before the Senate— In this discussion, the only ground alledged by Calhoun was the established rule, and the dissatisfaction which would be given by departing from it— Precedent and Popularity— This is the bent of his mind. The primary principles involved in any public question are the last that occur to him— What has been done, and what will be said are the Jachin and Boaz of his argument— Crawford talks more, and often of moral obligation; but his ethics are neither sound nor deep— He applies his principles with obliquity, and in most cases as in this, would have one rule for a State, and another for individuals, upon claims in which the ingredient of moral obligation was precisely the same. After the decision, Wirt said joking, well—if it goes to Congress, Virginia, may whistle for her interest— And why should not she, said I, when you make Massachusetts whistle for her principal— Because, said Wirt, Massachusetts is the Land of Song— As we came away Calhoun and Southard told me, that before I came in the discussion had been warm and even angry— Southard said he had given offence to Crawford, and Calhoun said he had been afraid he should be outvoted— That there had been an argument of their strongest man, Chapman Johnson, read, in favour of the claim, and Crawford very pertinacious for it— After the Meeting, I went for half an hour to my Office— Evening at the Theatre. The Honey Moon, and High Life below Stairs— The House was well filled; partly with Ladies of our Society— My Son John and Columbus Munroe had made it up as a party, and the company was of the first respectability— The Comedy was well performed— The farce is a picture of other manners than ours, and perhaps of other times in England.

3. VII.Mr T. Cook was here, about a negro woman, Jenny, belonging to Mrs Hellen, whom she wishes to sell, and the sale of whom to Mr Edwards I interposed to prevent— She has several Children—one an infant of about 6 Months, and another two years old— This last Mr Edwards would not take; and they were about separating her from that and all her other Children except the infant— The husband Basil, was actually sold to Governor Edwards, and he took him with him— But Jenny was not unwilling to part with him—
Mrs Hellen was determined to sell them all, and to save her from being separated from her Children, I promised to make good what they should sell for less than 200 dollars, the condition of Sale being that they should not be sold out of the District. Mr Cook however now informed me that this stipulation though often made is easily, and frequently evaded— At the Office, Captain Randall came, and the appropriation Bill having passed was now furnished with his papers for his departure— He is to leave the City next Wednesday. Mr Addington came to enquire concerning a Resolution of the House of Representatives passed at the instance of Edward Livingston of Louisiana, and the object of which was to ascertain if any Nation claimed certain rocks and Islats in the Gulph of Mexico, near the Coast of Florida— Addington said he had received a communication from the Governor of the Bahama Islands; informing him that they were within his Jurisdiction.— Mr Addington spoke also of the Act of the South-Carolina Legislature, concerning coloured persons arriving in the State, on board of ships; and said he had received a new express Instruction from his Government to make a new complaint, in the case of a British vessel from which three men had been taken to the great injury of the Captain. He asked what had been done in the case of which he had complained last Summer— I said that having learnt immediately after receiving his Letter that the man had been discharged, no farther measures had been taken concerning it. He said he was aware of the delicacy of the subject, and would avoid making any representation relating to it without absolute necessity— E. Wyer came and passed his half hour, in desultory Conversation— Evening at the Theatre— John Bull, and the Forest of Rosenwald, a Melodrama, upon the tale of Raymond and Agnes, or the bleeding Nun— The house less than half filled— Mr Southard walked home with me— Past Midnight before the performances closed— Mrs Adams for the first time left her chamber and dined with us below.

4. VII. Heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol, from 1. Chronicles 4.9.10 “And Jabez was more honourable than his brethren: and his mother called his name Jabez, saying, Because I bare him with sorrow— And Jabez called on the God of Israel, saying, Oh, that thou wouldest bless me indeed, and enlarge my Coast, and that thine hand might be with me, and that thou wouldest keep me from evil, that it may
not grieve me! And God granted him that which he requested.” Dr Staughton appears to affect originality if not singularity in the choice of his texts— He was upwards of an hour upon the character of Jabez, of whom nothing is said in the Bible, except in these two verses— After the service, I called to see Mr Bailey at Mrs Young’s. He was prevented from going last Thursday, by a severe return of his fever from which he is again convalescent. His intention now is to go next Thursday— On returning home I met at my door Robert S. Garnett, the member from Virginia, with Mr Pendleton, now a Member of the Executive Council of that State, and whom he introduced to me. E. Wyer was with them— I attended the afternoon service at Mr Baker’s, and heard Mr Russell, from Ecclesiastes 12.1. “Remember now thy Creator, in the days of thy Youth” A text the doctrine of which applies peculiarly to one period of life, but which the preacher generalized, and urged more by argument and less by pathos, than I should have expected— In the Evening I attended at Mr Little’s, and heard him from Luke 11.34–35. “The light of the body is the eye; therefore when thine eye is single, thy whole body also is full of light; but when thine eye is evil, thy body also is full of darkness. Take heed therefore, that the light which is in thee be not darkness.” Mr Little’s discourses are full of sound morality, when not too much mingled with controversial matter— While I was out this Evening, G. Sullivan, and Arthur Livermore, the member from New-Hampshire called to see me. Livermore left a Letter from N. Upham to him, which mentioned the resignation actual, or intended of Sherburne the District Judge, and advised Livermore to apply for the appointment himself.— I answered a Letter from the Secretary of the American Bible Society at New-York, S. S. Woodhull.

div.p:
5. V:30— Rose early with a view to industrious writing— Found my room occupied by chimney sweepers, and other occupations awaiting me for two hours— Missed my time of writing till near breakfast, hour, and could not afterwards recover it— Mr Little came to ask a document for correcting the Press, of the Commercial Supplementary document compiled by him for a Report to Congress— Also to ask aid to obtain employment of writing in the Land-Office. G. Sullivan brought me a copy of a Letter from W. Eustis, when Secretary of War, to W. King in July 1812. calling upon him to muster two Regiments of Volunteers; and this he states to be the foundation of the allowance in 1820. of pay to King for ten Months, as a Major-General of the Militia of Massachusetts, in the service of the United States. Sullivan appears to be extremely anxious to distinguish this case from that of the remainder of the Militia claim of Massachusetts— For as this was paid by order of the President seven years after the transaction occurred, if the President was authorized so to allow, was he not alike authorized to sanction the payment of the whole claim? He was unable to point out any such distinction. He said his
Colleague Pearce had obtained more than a month since copies of these papers, he supposed, by information of their existence from King himself, or at the suggestion of Mr Webster— Arthur Livermore came to speak of the appointment of District Judge in New Hampshire, in the event of Mr Sherburne’s resignation; and W. Plumer followed soon after— Plumer had declined signing a written recommendation of Livermore, but spoke of him as well qualified for the Office— Plumer named also Mr Bell, the Senator, Levi Woodbury, the present Governor, and Jeremiah Mason of Portsmouth as persons who might be recommended, and all well worthy of the Station. He spoke too of the Presidential Election—the present prospects in New York, the anxious efforts of Mr Calhoun and his friends, now to obtain the support of mine, for his election to the Vice-Presidency— The solicitations of Rogers and Hamilton in his behalf, and Calhoun’s unfitness for the place. The uncertainty whether Jackson and his friends wish that he may be supported for the Vice-Presidency or not, and the overture from Burton, of the wish that my friends would support Nathanael Macon for Vice-President. I requested Plumer to converse with J. W. Taylor, and with Mr Seymour of Vermont, and consult them as to the expediency of ascertaining the dispositions of Genl. Jackson’s friends— Mr Burleigh, member from Maine was here to make enquiry about an order for the release of a person from prison in that State— Mr Burton came with a Dr Bradford and Mr Pendleton, both of Virginia— While they were here Mr George Hay came in, and they immediately went away— Hay spoke of Bradford and Pendleton, as of persons both well known to him— And he told me that with regard to the agency before the Slave-indemnity Commission he had concluded to give it up altogether— He said that in conversing with Mr Roane, now here, he had spoken of young Pleasants the son of the Governor of Virginia, and now Editor of the Constitutional Whig, a Newspaper at Richmond, as of an unprincipled man, and in reality no friend of mine; and Hay asked me, if I would permit him to communicate to Roane, what had passed between Pleasants and me here last Winter— I said no— Reminding him that his own knowledge of the whole correspondence had arisen from peculiar Circumstances which occurred at the time. That however unjustifiable Pleasants’s conduct to me had been, he had begun by reposing Confidence in me. He had finished by apologising to me for his wrongs, and I could not feel myself justified in exposing him— Hay said this was sufficient and he should say nothing more to
Roane, upon the subject. Mr Frye was twice here—first to say that he wished to send the Deeds exhibiting the titles of Mr Johnson’s heirs to the Lands in Georgia, to Mr Ringgold at Augusta; and secondly to tell me, that Mr Southard had spoken severely against me at table at his Lodgings last Saturday, censuring something I had said at the Cabinet Meeting the day before— And that Mr Crowninshield was present. I told Frye there was certainly a mistake—as there had been no disagreement of opinion between Mr Southard and me at the Cabinet Meeting on Friday, and no misunderstanding between us, at any other time— Frye said his authority was Genl. D. Parker, who had his information from De Hart, a young Jerseyman lodging at Mrs Wilson’s, and who was at the table— Blunt was at my house, and afterwards at the Office. He wanted information concerning my Mission in Russia, and is going next Friday for New-York— At the Office Mr Savage repeated his solicitation for the appointment of Consul General at Guatimala, with a temporary Salary— I again dissuaded him from expecting it, and told him I would give him a definitive answer from the President to-morrow. At the President’s— I had received a note from Mr Silvestre Rebello, announcing himself as Charge d’Affaires from his Majesty the Emperor of Brazil, and asking an interview in that capacity— Enclosing at the same time, a Letter to me from the Brazilian Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. The Empire of Brazil has not yet been recognized, and the question is whether it shall now be recognized by the reception of Mr Rebello. The President directed a Cabinet Meeting to be called at one to-morrow. I suggested also to the President of appointing Mr Gallatin, upon a special mission to Great-Britain, to be joined in the Negotiations now confided to Mr Rush alone, and with a Commission to take the place of Mr Rush on his return home—which he has announced his intention of effecting the next autumn— The President said that he did not expect any thing would be effected by the present Negotiations of Mr Rush upon any one point; not even upon the Slave-trade— That his intention had been to leave the appointment of the successor to Mr Rush in the English Mission to his own Successor— I said that probably before Mr Rush’s return some decided opinion might be formed as to who would be the successor to the Presidency, and the appointment might be made with his concurrence— That my own wish would be in favour of Mr Gallatin and partly to relieve him from an aukward situation in which he had been placed, doubtless with his own consent, but with no present appearance of success by his Caucus nomination for the Vice-Presidency— I considered Mr Gallatin, by his Talents, and his services peculiarly fitted for, and entitled to the Mission to Great-Britain, and I should be sorry to see him entirely discarded from the service of this Country— The President said he was confident no person other than a native of the United States would be chosen Vice-President,
nor would the People of this Union ever forget Mr Gallatin’s having quitted the Treasury Department at its utmost need in 1813. But he concurred entirely with me that Mr Gallatin was eminently fitted for the Mission to Great Britain, and wished with me that he might receive no mark of disrespect from the Nation— Of the proposal to appoint him the successor to Mr Rush, he would consider further— I dined with Sullivan, and a small party—Messrs. Knowles, Rice, Appleton, Rich, and Poinsett, D. P. Cook and Blunt— Went after dinner with Cook to the Theatre, and saw the last Act of Gilderroy, a dull Melodrama, and the Irishman in London— Anderson in Murtoch Delany was above mediocrity.

div.p:
6. VII.Lewis Williams of North-Carolina was here, with a young man named Mullet, and Eleazar Early, a travelling Presidential canvasser for Mr Crawford— George Johnson came to tell me the state of affairs concerning the Mill— Their actual condition is no better than heretofore, but their prospects are a little improved— Still extremely precarious. At one, I attended the Cabinet Meeting. Calhoun, Southard and Wirt were present— The question was presented by the President, whether Mr Silvestre Rebello should be received as Chargè d’Affaires from His Majesty the Emperor of Brazil, and the Independence of that Country be thereby acknowledged— Mr Wirt questioned the expediency of this measure, principally on the ground that the revolutionary Government established there was monarchical, and not Republican. Mr Calhoun was warmly in favour of the recognition; distinguishing between the question of Independence, and that of internal Government. Mr Wirt thought that an immediate recognition of the Brazilian Empire, would be represented as favouring the views of the Holy Alliance, and a partiality for Monarchies—and alluded to General Jackson’s refusal of the Mission to Mexico, when Yturbide was Emperor, and to the publication of his Letter assigning as his reason for the refusal that he would give no countenance to that Usurpation— Mr Calhoun said that the established policy of this Country in relation to South-America, had been to look only to the question of Independence, and invariably to recognize the Governments defacto. That we had thus recognized the imperial Government of Yturbide, and received a minister from him. That to decline the recognition of the Empire of Brazil, because it was monarchical would be a departure from the policy hitherto observed, and would introduce a new principle of interference in the internal Government of foreign Nations— That the acknowledgment of the
Independence of Brazil was highly important, our trade thither being already very considerable, and promising to be more valuable than with all the rest of South-America— The President observed that the recognition of Brazil, as an Empire, would lessen the offensiveness to the Holy Alliance, of all the acknowledgments, as it would shew that we did not make a difference, with regard to the forms of Government. I said there were reasons for the recognition of Brazil, yet stronger than those which had operated in the case of Spanish America, in as much as the King of Portugal himself while he resided in Brazil had proclaimed it an Independent kingdom, and abolished the Colonial system of Government altogether— But of the revolutionary changes since the return of the old king to Portugal, we had not been authentically notified— I proposed therefore, that I should be authorised to see Mr Rebello, and call upon him for a statement of facts, authenticated by Documents, shewing the independent condition of Brazil de facto; and that the recognition should be founded thereon— Which was accordingly determined— The President then said he had been strongly urged to send a Message to Congress, referring to them the claim of Virginia for the payment of interest which had been declined as an allowance by Executive authority; and he read the draft which he had prepared of such a message— Some slight alteration of one of the paragraphs was proposed, but no objection was made to the sending of the Message itself. The President further intimated his intention of nominating B. Watts of South-Carolina, as Secretary of Legation to Colombia, and sending Mr Mann of North-Carolina, as special agent to Guatimala: and he mentioned that he had at length nominated B. Bates for re-appointment as Collector of the port of Bristol, Rhode-Island— There was heavy rain, the greater part of this day, and the weather cleared off with a Gale this Evening. Mrs Adams’s party was in consequence very thinly attended— About 70 persons— Mr Rebello came with Coll. Torrens, and I desired him to call at two to-morrow at the Office of the Department of State. Mr R. King, Senator from New-York was here. Left with me a Letter from H. Wheaton at Albany; of 2. April since his return. From that and other Letters, nothing decisive can be collected of the dispositions of the New-York Legislature— Yates the present Governor, was dropp’d in the caucus nomination for Governor—60 votes for Young: 45 for Yates— 106 members present. 54. absent— 75 for Root as Lieutenant Governor— No confirmation of the Congressional Caucus nomination at this City. But this Yates Root writes, may come hereafter. It is certain however that there will be no manifestation of opinion against the Congressional Caucus.
G. Hay told me there had been sharp words, in the Tariff debate this day, in the House, between Hamilton of South-Carolina, & Martindale of New-York— And assured me that he himself never in his life lost his temper in a public debate; and that his coolness had often given him an advantage over Chapman Johnson. I asked Crowninshield, if Southard had said any thing hostile to me in his presence last Saturday. He said no— He might have said something by way of joke; but was as friendly to me as possible— Southard himself told me that great pains had been taken to exasperate Crawford against him, and that Mrs Miller had charged him with unfair and ungenerous conduct to Crawford in his illness; altogether without cause— Southard spoke also of a private Note which he had written to James Lloyd of the Senate on the Navy Appropriation Bill; which had by mistake been given over to M’Lane Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means of the House; who had asked Lloyd, whether he might read it in the house— Lloyd answered no: but demanded the note back, and returned it to Southard. He said they were for making a dead set at him, but would get nothing by it. Mrs. Adams was obliged to retire this Evening, before the company went away.

7. VII.Governor Miller of the Arkansas territory came to take leave upon his intended return to pass the Summer in New-Hampshire for the restoration of his health. He asked if it would be necessary for him to obtain a permission of absence from his Territory in writing. I thought it doubtful whether the President could grant him a formal leave of absence, and supposed it must rest on the apparent necessity to complete his recovery— Blunt was here; afterwards at the Office, and dined with us— He examined the first Volume of my public Correspondence from Russia, which he wished to consult for information concerning the political Events of that time— At two Mr Silvestre Rebello came to the Office, and delivered to me the Letter from Mr Carvalho e Mello, Minister of Foreign Affairs to the Emperor of Brazil, announcing him in the character of Brazilian Charge d’Affaires— I told him that in our recognition of the Spanish South-American Nations, we had proceeded upon authenticated and official documents announcing the changes in their Governments; but none such had been received from the Brazilian Government— I invited him therefore to send me a written statement of the facts, accompanied by document vouchers, with translations, as it was probable they would all be communicated to Congress and to the Public.
He said he would prepare and send me such an exposition of facts; and accompanied by the documents— That the king of Portugal himself had in the year 1817 (it was in 1815) proclaimed Brazil an Independent Kingdom, and as such it had been recognized by the European Powers.— That after his return to Portugal, the Brazilian Nation had exercised its own right, and had constituted itself an Empire— This was a mere word— It implied an extensive territory, which could not be applicable to Portugal; but was eminently so to Brazil— Its meaning however was only that Brazil was an independent Nation— And its Government was in principle Republican— The Emperor himself, being more inclined to Republicanism than the People of the Country. That the Documents were all public, and if the Government of the United States had not received them it was the fault of their Agent, in omitting to forward them— I said we were possessed of the documents; but it was necessary that we should have them officially authenticated— He said he would send translations, but enquired if it was not matter of right for him to make his communications in his own language— I answered certainly; but that we had no person here sufficiently versed in the Portuguese language to make the translations so correctly as I should wish to have them, of these papers— And I remarked that all the Portuguese public Agents in this Country hitherto had written in English or in French— He said he would make me the communication as soon as possible and took leave— Mr Baker the clergyman came and introduced to me Mr Seixas a Hebrew of the Hebrews who is a teacher of that language— Mr Bailey came and took leave; going to-morrow, for Canton; and Captain Randall, going to embark for the Havanna. Evening at the Theatre— Speed the Plough—poorly performed; and the Forest of Rosenwald, better.

8. VII.15.Coll. Richard M. Johnson came, and recommended Mr Overton, as District Attorney in Pensacola, in the place of W. F. Steele, if he should be removed— Also C. Savage for the Consulate in Guatimala, which he solicits. The Coll. spoke also of the Presidential Election; and of his recent conversations with Govr. Barbour, of Virginia, M. Van Buren of New-York, and Jesse B. Thomas of Illinois— Thomas is yet ardent and sanguine, as at any former period. Van Buren still puts on a good face, and professes to expect final success.— Barbour seems ready to give up the cause. The nomination of Young as the Candidate for Governor, in preference to Yates the present incumbent is considered too much as a defeat of Van Buren’s party, and an indication of the decay of his influence. Johnson said he had seen a Letter from a friend of Clay’s stating that they would agree upon an electoral ticket of 18 for Clay and 18 for me; but all to vote, for one or the other according to the prospects of success. At the Office came J. N. Harmes
a native of Bremen, but naturalized a Citizen of the U.S and residing in Philadelphia— He has applied for the appointment of Consul at Bremen, but that is not vacant; and for a Passport, which was given him— Like many other applicants he thought it sufficient for the removal of the present Officer that he has held the appointment many years— The British Chargé d’Affaires Addington, brought an answer to a Note which I had written him some weeks since enquiring of the authenticity of a notice published in a Newspaper by the Vice-Consul at Portland, Maine, concerning an Act of the Legislature of the Island of Jamaica— I had a general Conversation with him on the subject— J. H. Eaton, Senator from Tennessee, called; respecting certain papers— E. Wyer paid his daily visit— Company to dine. Messrs.Mark Alexander, Burwell Bassett, T. H. Benton, J. W. Cady, J. C. Calhoun, J. W. Campbell, John Chandler, Matthew St. Clair Clarke, Ela Collins, Henry Conner, Charles Cutts, Lewis Eaton, Robert Harris, Joseph Kent, James M’Ilvaine, Louis M’Lane, and Samuel L. Southard. There had been invited John Branch, John Long, W. H. Roane, and W. Wirt who did not come. Mrs Adams was not well enough to dine with us. Blunt was here in the Evening— Going to-morrow for New-York. Close of the Evening at the Theatre. Saw the last Act of Gilderroy; and the Duel, or my two Nephews—a farce rather dull and indifferently performed— Mr. Newton, the member from Norfolk, Virginia, had been here this morning, and spoke of an Amendment proposed by Mr Webster to the Tariff Bill, to alter the impost upon Wines— Its object being to diminish the present duties— I thought with regard to the French wines, they should be left to obtain some equivalent for reducing them. Newton said he would speak of it to Mr Webster.

9. VII:15.Mr Knowles of Charlestown, was here this morning. Going to-morrow Morning, upon his return home— Very anxious upon the Presidential Election— And particularly to determine whether it will be expedient for my friends to support General Jackson for the Vice-Presidency. I told him I thought it advisable that they should, until something from General Jackson or his friends should distinctly signify an unwillingness that he should be voted for in that capacity. And in that case I should personally be satisfied if they would support Nathaniel Macon of North-Carolina— At the Office, Mr Savage came for the answer to his application for the appointment of Consul General to Guatimala— I told him I would see the President, and give him his answer to-morrow. I
called at the President’s, but he was riding out. Mr Cowper of Norfolk, Virginia, came and made some enquiries concerning my title to the dwelling-house, in which I live, and the land upon which it stands. He brought with him an original deed to Thomas C. Cox of the lot N. 8 Square 253. the same on which the house stands, dated 14. Feby. 1804. and said his enquiries, were in behalf of the legal Representatives of this Cox—and he had a copy of a previous lease of 29. June 1802 from Templeman to Voss— He left the deeds with me, and upon examination among my papers I found minutes of both of them, and among the Deeds given over to me, when I purchased the place, one from this same Cox to A. and G. Way of 28. May 1813. It would seem as if the original Deed to Cox had come to the hands of his Representatives, without any notice that he had sold the Estate. Mr John Mason jr. came to ask for the Presidents decision upon his claim for the allowance of Salary to him as Secretary to the Legation to Mexico, from the time of his appointment, fourteen Months back— I told him the President had decided to allow him half a years salary, previous to the date of Mr N. Edwards’s Commission— Some compensation being due to him, for his abandonment of other pursuits; but not the whole time; as that would amount to more than a year’s Salary, without any performance of duty— He then said he was to meet Mr Edwards at New-Orleans the first of June, and there they were to embark in the porpoise for Mexico— But he had a Letter from Mr Edwards, since he left this place— He had had a relapse of his disorder— He had extensive private concerns to settle at home— What was he to do, if Mr Edwards should not reach New-Orleans at the appointed time? His own wish was to go on without him— I told him I would take and inform him of the President’s directions— The President sent me a project by Mr Crawford, of an answer to M’Lane, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, concerning the suppression of the fourth Auditor’s Office— Crawford recommends it; and proposes that its duties should in substance be transferred to the fifth auditor. Mr Calhoun and Mr Southard are against the suppression, and the President sent to require my opinion, with reference to the Department of State; being that the accounts connected with which are submitted to the 5th. Auditor. I sent for Mr Pleasonton; read to him Mr Crawford’s proposed answer to M’Lane; and asked him if he could take upon him the additional service, thereby allotted to him— He said not unless relieved from the Agency for conducting the prosecutions of the Government, for debts due to the Treasury; and from the superintendence of the Light houses, both of which were supernumerary to all his duties as an Auditor— I requested him to make a written statement of all the services with which he is charged, which he promised to do.
E. Wyer called at the Office— Evening at the Theatre— [“]Wives as they were, and Maids as they Are”—with the farce of Turn out; substituted for another— Performance better than usual. Walking home, Mr Southard spoke of W. Lowrie’s publication in the Newspapers. And of Mr Crawford’s having this day withdrawn the Treasury Patronage from the Washington City Gazette; in consequence of a violent personal attack upon the President, in that paper of last Tuesday.

10. VII:30—Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General called this morning at my house; and enquired, if I had heard lately from Mr. T. B. Johnson. He said Mr Johnson had some time since written to him expressing the intention to resign his Office as Postmaster at New-Orleans; but the applications for the place were so numerous, and it was so unpleasant to select between them, that he wished Mr Johnson would keep it. I said we had not very recently heard from him, but understood his intention was to resign about this time; owing to the state of his health which he found it impossible to retain in the climate of New-Orleans. I gave Mr M’Lean a Letter from Mr Pitman, the U.S. District Attorney at Providence, Rhode-Island, recommending the appointment of a person as Postmaster there; requesting him to return the Letter to me. He spoke also of the equivocal appearances in New-York, respecting the Presidential Election, and said that an explicit manifestation of opinion in New-York, would be equally decisive in Ohio and Indiana. This however is not now to be expected— Mr Newton of Virginia came and introduced a Mr M’Intosh, from Norfolk— Visit also from F. Coyle, tax collector for the City Corporation— At the Office Mr Savage called for his answer, which, not having seen the President I was not able to give him, this day— I called at the President’s with the Note received from Addington, complaining of the South-Carolina Law, which I left with him— He said he would nominate Savage, as Consul at any Port in Guatimala— I told him the substance of the Conversation I had had with Mr Rebello, and observed that in the Event of his recognition and reception, it would be necessary to nominate Mr Raguet, or some other person, as Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro, as the informal agency of Mr Raguet would become afterwards questionable in a Constitutional point of view— The President thought the appointment of a Charge d’Affaires to Brazil, might still be postponed, and asked if the nomination of Raguet would be supported by the Senators from Pennsylvania— I proposed to enquire of them, and said I had no reason to doubt of it; unless perhaps Mr Lowry should object to Raguet for some taint of federalism. This led the President to speak of
Lowry’s late publication in the American Sentinel of Philadelphia, recently republished in the National Intelligencer. (See ante. 27. Feby.) On the 15th. of March Lowry wrote a second Letter to the President, stating explicitly that he P.U.S. had read to him and Findlay, a Letter from Genl. Jackson to him, recommending to him to form his Cabinet of distinguished individuals of both the great political parties— Then adverting to the recent denials in the Newspapers, which he says have given rise to imputations upon his character, and to reproachful Letters from persons, whose confidence he had heretofore enjoyed— Lowry therefore demands of the President that he would publish Jackson’s Letter to him— Some days after this, A. Stevenson called upon the President at Lowry’s request, and asked if he had received Lowry’s Letter of 15. March, and if an answer to it might be expected. The President told Stevenson that he had received that, and a preceding Letter from Lowry— That the first of them was in an adversary attitude, announcing himself to be in possession of a Letter, written by him the President, and that he had not determined what to do with it— He had received this Letter, under a blank cover from Richmond; but it had come from a person who had no right to it, and there was a breach of trust or dishonesty somewhere in the process of its coming to his possession— The second Letter did not alter the attitude, and while that continued, Mr Lowrie must take his own course— After this Stevenson called again upon the President, and declared on Lowry’s part, that he had not in writing the first Letter the most distant intention of menacing, or assuming a hostile position; and requesting to withdraw that Letter; but the President declined returning it— Lowry then, on the first of this Month wrote to the Editors of the Sentinel at Philadelphia, requesting them to publish his Letter to the President of 15. March, preceded, by an Article from the Democratic Press of 20. Jany. introducing Kremer’s Letter of 17. Jany—and by an Article from the Franklin Gazette of 30. January, declaring an explicit denial of Mr Findlay that the President had ever read to him, such a Letter from Genl. Jackson— In his Letter to the Editors of the Sentinel, Lowry says he hopes no after event will compel him to publish the incontrovertible evidence that he possesses; meaning doubtless thereby his surreptitious prize, the President’s answer to Jackson— The President said that he supposed General Jackson would some day publish his Letter; but would chuse his own time for it— Throughout the whole transaction, the President said he saw nothing to regret, excepting the misplaced confidence that he had bestowed, by alluding to the contents of Jackson’s Letter, to persons who had proved unworthy of the trust— But he said he was confident he had not read any Letter of Jackson’s to Lowry and Findlay— And Findlay’s recollection concurred with his— Findlay himself had declared to him; that he, Mr Monroe had never read to him and Lowry; any Letter from Jackson, whatsoever—
The President then adverted to another subject of which he had never before spoken to me; but which for years has given him trouble. On the 3d. of March 1817. there was appropriated 20000 dollars, and on the 20th. of April 1818. 30000 dollars, for furnishing the President’s house; to be expended under his direction. He charged Coll. Lane, Commissioner of the Public Buildings chiefly with it. Lane died about a year and a half ago, a defaulter for several thousand dollars, and rumours have since been in obscure circulation, that the President himself had used large sums of the money and thereby occasioned the defalcation— At the last Session of Congress John Cocke, Member of the House from Tennessee, instituted in the House an enquiry concerning the state of Lane’s Accounts after his decease; and finding upon examination indications that the President had received a part of the money, sent him a message to enquire if he would appear before the Committee, to answer interrogatories, or give explanations concerning these expenditures— He desired the person who brought him the Message to tell Cocke that he was a scoundrel, and that that was the only answer he would give him— Cocke had then intended to make a Report, but the Committee which had been raised at his instance would not agree to it— At the present Session of Congress Cocke had again raised a Committee on the subject, and is pushing the investigation to a Report— In the meantime charges have been raised against Cocke himself, of having embezzled monies received by him as an agent for certain Pensioners. He has been attacked about it, in the Washington Republican; and the attack upon the President in last Tuesday’s Gazette was by way of retaliation, and written by Colvin. It was for this paper, that Mr Crawford withdrew from the Gazette the Patronage of the Treasury Department; upon the admonition as Wirt told Southard, of Mr Catlet of Alexandria,—a warm friend both of the President, and of Mr Crawford— The President now read me the draft of a Message, prepared to send in to Congress, requesting the appointment of a Committee to investigate his Accounts, and his management of public monies entrusted to him during the whole time that he has been in the public Service—since his first Mission to France in 1794. And with this he put into my hands two Memoirs, one upon his claims for further allowances, upon his Missions to Europe, and the other upon his transactions with Coll. Lane respecting the two Appropriations for furnishing the President’s house. He spoke of his forbearance to dismiss Colvin from the Department of State;—of Colvin’s treachery to Robert Smith, who had placed him in the Department— Said Colvin had afterwards offered to write for him in the Newspapers, which he had declined. He had always kept him
employed on service not confidential— When Mr Madison’s Administration drew to a close, and he Mr Monroe was before the Nation as a Candidate for the Presidency, Colvin wrote in the newspapers against him; and after the election in his favour— I told the President that Colvin had treated me much in the same manner— At first with flattery that I had nauseated; then by neglect of duty, and groveling vices, till I had been compelled to dismiss him from Office; and by lampooning me from that day to this in the City Gazette. He had rung all the possible charges of falsehood against me, from the barest lie to the most insidious misrepresentations. But he could alledge at least against me that I had taken from him his place, which was his bread— For his baseness to Mr Monroe he had no provocation. On returning to the Office I found Wyer there— Dined with my Son John at Mr Clay’s— Company of the foreign Missions and members of Congress— Among them Mr Taliaferro, the new member from Virginia— G. Hay was also there— Evening at the Theatre which closed with the Iron Chest, and Who’s the Dupe,—Sir Edward Mortimer and old D’Oiley, by a strolling Adventurer named Pemberton, who has been giving recitations of his own poetry, and performs with the Company only for this Night.— He has very considerable talents— The house was crowded— Mrs Adams and the Girls were there— Bradley of Vermont came in to the box, and told me he had been dining with Gales, and making discoveries.

11. VII:15. Heard at Mr Baker’s, this morning, Mr Finlay of Baltimore; from Philippians 1.9.10. “And this I pray that your love may abound yet more and more in knowledge and in all judgment;—That ye may approve things that are excellent; that ye may be sincere and without offence till the day of Christ.” and this afternoon from Ezekiel 33.11. “Say unto them, As I live saith the Lord God, I have no pleasure in the Death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way and live: turn ye, turn ye from your evil ways; for, why will ye die, O house of Israel?” This preacher has great volubility, and great vehemence— He will therefore pass for eloquent; but the substance of his discourses is common place. In the evening, I attended at Mr Little’s. He preached from 1. Corin: 1.22. and two following verses—“For the Jews require a sign, and the Greeks seek after wisdom: But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumbling block, and unto the Greeks foolishness; But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God.” The comment on the text was mingled with the usual dose of the Unitarian doctrines— After returning home, I wrote, journalizing for a couple of hours.— G. Sullivan came this day and mentioned to me, that he had received a Letter from Governor Eustis, who he said would not listen at-all to his resignation of the Agency for the claim, but insisted upon his retaining it. He manifests however no disposition to give up or recall Peirce; and I told Sullivan that if Peirce’s intention was such as he apprehended I thought
he ought to insist either upon Peirce’s recall, or upon resigning himself, or upon Peirce’s being instructed by the Governor to desist from his intention of opposing before the Committee the course of Sullivan’s argument to them— I observed that I had not seen his recent Correspondence with Peirce; upon which he went home, and brought it over. It was different from what I had expected— Evasive on the part of Peirce; and rather complaining that documents unnecessary had been improperly transmitted to Congress, than avowing the intention of exhibiting others. Sullivan insists that Peirce is acting entirely under the influence and dictation of Webster; and that Fuller is also governed by him. I urged strongly upon Sullivan the necessity of having the Message on the Claim referred to a Committee of the House, and of obtaining a favourable Report upon it at this Session. He said he would take this into Consideration; but he is averse to having it committed at-all, at this Session— I read this day the President’s Memoir upon the transactions relating to the appropriations for furnishing the President’s House. It enters into details of a very humiliating character, and which ought never to have been or to be required of him.— The principal difficulty appears to have sprung from his having used his own furniture, until that provided for by the Appropriations could be procured, and having received for it 6000 dollars to be repaid, upon the redelivery of his furniture to him— This produced an intermingling of Lane’s public and private accounts with him, which by Lane’s sickness and death remained unsettled at his decease— There arises from all this an exposure of domestic and household concerns, almost as incongruous to the station of a President of the United States, as it would be to a blooming virgin, to exhibit herself naked before a multitude. The malignity of political opposition has no feeling of delicacy— There appears to be nothing really censurable in all these transactions, but Lane was an unfortunate selection of an Agent, and his final insolvency has produced all these aukward consequences.

12. VI:45.George’s birth day—23. Mr George Hay called this Morning, irritated at a paragraph in the National Intelligencer of this day, which he considers as intended to convey an indirect censure upon him: and he confidentially told me that Coll. Mosher intended to set up a new Paper here, and wished to obtain for it the Patronage of the Departments of the Government— The President did not think proper to interfere in that respect, but he would give for the paper a copy of the Message, as early as to the National Intelligencer— I told him that this might give some circulation to the paper, but that the Patronage of the Departments generally did, and ought always to follow that of Congress, and that
the Editors of the Intelligencer had the patronage of Congress, by Election— He said the Editors of the Intelligencer were three times over insolvent, and I told him, although I was sensible of the baseness of their conduct towards Mr Monroe, and their real hostility to him, I should yet regret, on account of their families to see their establishment broken up, as it must be if the patronage of Congress should be withdrawn from them— He spoke of the withdrawal of the Land-Office, advertising, from the Washington Gazette, and said that he had called last week on Mr George Graham, Commissioner of the Land-Office, and told him if it should be continued, he would make it a ground of direct, specific charge against Mr Crawford before the Nation— And that shortly afterwards Asbury Dickins had called on Mr Graham with directions from Mr Crawford to discontinue the advertising in the Gazette— Mr Hay talked on various other topics; but I presume the principal object of his call, was the project of the new paper. Dr Spence, a member of the House from Maryland, came and introduced a Mr Dennis— They spoke of this Slave-indemnity Commission, and of their adjournment till June: enquiring whether the sufferers might expect their indemnity soon— I could give them no promising hopes; the purpose of the British Commissioner and arbitrator; being evidently to procrastinate and defeat the object of the Commission. Mr Charles S. Todd recently returned from the Republic of Colombia came; having arrived this morning from Charleston South-Carolina. He declined accepting the appointment of Secretary of Legation, to Mr Anderson, and soon after his arrival at Bogota, left that Country. He was some weeks detained by sickness at Charleston. He speaks of the political state of the Country in the Republic of Colombia, as very precarious— At the Office Mr Savage came, and I told him the President would nominate him as Consul at the City of Guatimala— He was entering into a long detail of his projects and intentions, and how it would affect his personal Affairs; which I interrupted, by telling him that his personal affairs were his own, and the Government had nothing to do with them— The appointments of the Government were made upon public considerations, and it was for every individual to consider whether the appointment offered him would suit him or not— He then said he would take time to determine whether to accept the appointment or not. This man has worn down my Patience, till I had none left— William Lee came to tell me, that Timothy Pickering’s book against my father in answer to the Cunningham pamphlet, was in the Press, and would be immediately published— Mr Slacum came for an answer to his solicitation for the appointment of Consul at Buenos-Ayres; but the President had not yet determined upon it. Wyer came on his daily visit— John W. Taylor called on me this Evening, and said Plumer had spoken to him of the expediency of applying
to General Jackson or some of his friends to ascertain whether it would be agreeable to him to be supported for the Vice-Presidency, by my friends— That he had casually put the question to judge Isacks of Tennessee, who intimated that it would be pleasing to him; but said he would speak with Taylor, of it, again.— I said that since the meeting in New-York, the prospect of a powerful effort in that State, to support Jackson for the Presidency was so great that I thought it best to let the thing take its own course, and make no application to him or his friends, with reference to the Vice-Presidency— Taylor said his belief was that Tallmadge was endeavouring to get up a party for Jackson and that the project of the Convention at Utica, was formed with that intention. Though Marvin, and Hayden and Martindale; he said were of a different opinion— I said I had never expected any thing from the project of a Convention, and that if the popular voice should not be really in Jackson’s favour it would easily be seen by calling Meetings to express different opinions— Taylor thinks that the assumption by the Albany Caucus of Young, for their Candidate as Governor, was the result of a bargain, and that its object was to prevent the opposite party from setting up Young in opposition to Yates— And he thought it probable, that all this mining and countermining, might ultimately compel my friends, to fall in and support Young and Crawford, to keep out Jackson— The result of all is that New-York has been and will be bargained away. Taylor said that since he had spoken to me at the House, he had seen General Brown, who had told him that Mr Calhoun’s friends wished him to be in the next Administration, in a more active situation than that of Vice-President; but he himself inclined to the Vice-Presidency—probable for the sake of a certainty of not being entirely thrown out of place— And he asked Taylor what he thought would be my views, in this respect. Taylor said he did not know; but had no reason to suppose that I would remove Calhoun from his present Office. Dix afterwards hinted to Taylor that Calhoun’s friends wished him to be Secretary of the Treasury; a place which it was supposed might be vacant— I told Taylor the time had certainly not yet come if it ever should, for me to think of these arrangements; I had no hesitation in saying; that I should have no disposition to remove Mr Calhoun.— Nor had I any reason for concluding that in the Event of my election the Department of the Treasury would be vacant. I suppose that the principal object of General Brown’s Soundings was to ascertain whether I would dismiss Crawford, and appoint Calhoun in his place— On parting from me, Taylor concluded—To take no further step at present, but to wait for the progress of Events— He says that General Jackson admits that he wrote to the President a Letter somewhat resembling that which Lowrie asserts that the President read to him and Findlay; but that too much consequence has been attached to it— And Lowrie, he says feels quite easy since his publication.

13. VI:30.Professor Griscom, a Quaker, author of a Book, entitled, “A year in Europe,[”] came with Letters of Introduction from C. D. Colden, and N. H. Carter— He is projecting a new Scientific periodical work, and wished for copies of papers from the Patent Office; for which I referred him to Dr. Thornton, and W. Elliot— Mr Cowper of Norfolk, Virginia called at my House, upon the enquiry concerning the Deeds he had brought me— I had left them at the Office, together with my own papers, expecting he would have called again there.— I told him of the Deed of August 1813. from Coxe to A and G. Way, and gave him the minute of its Record, with which he declared himself entirely satisfied— But he will call again for his Deeds— Mr Durfee a member from Rhode-Island, came and introduced Coll. Thomas Rivers of Providence, who brought me Letters of Introduction, from Henry Edes the Clergyman, and from Dutee J. Pearce— He comes to solicit the appointment of Postmaster now vacant at that place; but says he has been forestalled by Wheeler the Editor of the Providence Patriot, who has bespoken the influence of the whole Delegation— Mr Mosher came and spoke to me of his, or rather I suspect Mr George Hay’s project of setting up a new Paper. I told him of the difficulties with which it would have to encounter, and that its success must entirely depend upon its supplanting the National Intelligencer, which would be no easy thing— The Editors of that print were indeed giving great dissatisfaction, probably to a majority of Congress by the disingenuous course they were pursuing in regard to the Presidential Election. But they still kept within bounds reconcileable to any of the Candidates who might succeed, other than their own— And whenever the Election of Printers to Congress should come on, the destruction of their establishment by the British in 1814 would be remembered in their favour— And after all the question will remain whether Congress can expect to gain anything by a change. An establishment which should report the debates in Congress even as well as they do could not easily be formed— I said the Washington Republican was a partizan paper which had never paid its expenses, and which could not in my opinion survive the present year— Having the irredeemable defect of being edited by an Englishman, not yet naturalized— Mosher said Mr Calhoun was of the same opinion— General Call the Delegate from the Territory of Florida, came to renew an enquiry which he had some time since made, whether the Article in the Florida, providing indemnity for suffers by the late proceedings of the Army of the United States in that province, would include their proceedings during the late War with Great-Britain—which it certainly does not.— He spoke also of the complaints against W. F. Steele the District Attorney there, whom he earnestly defends— At the Office Mr Savage came, and consented to be nominated as Consul for the City of Guatemala and the adjoining Country. And Mr W. H. Allen of Maryland, a Candidate for appointment as Commissioner
of Land-titles in East-Florida; in the place of Alexander Hamilton, who he said he heard had resigned— This Evening I attended with my Son John, the concert given by Mr Pearman, Mrs Burke, and Mr Clifton. The Hall at Williamson’s was well filled. The music good, but not of a high order.

14. VI:30:Mr M’Kean, a member of the House from Pennsylvania, came and introduced a Mr Backus, now and for many years a resident of that State, but originally from Massachusetts— Mr Crowninshield followed, and introduced a Mr Moore, now a New-Yorker but also a native of Massachusetts— Moore told me he would call on me again to-morrow, wishing to have some private conversation with me. W. Plumer was here, and spoke of his conversations with J. W. Taylor, upon the expediency of ascertaining the views of General Jackson, with regard to the Vice-Presidency. All the General’s friends to whom it had been mentioned, approved, and desired that my friends should support him for that Office— But Taylor had concluded not to say any thing of it to him— I concurred in this and observed that as the support by my friends of General Jackson, would rest upon its only proper ground, the fitness of the thing, I should prefer it infinitely to any bargaining for support to myself. Dr Kent, a member from Maryland came to repeat the recommendation of W. G. D. Worthington for an appointment to some South-American Mission or Agency. He is a man of good intentions; of flighty imagination, of weak judgment, and of overflowing vanity— And withal so indiscreet that he cannot be employed in any service of trust, without making himself ridiculous. Yet his honesty, his helplessness, and his wants, with a large family to support, make him many friends who urgently recommend him for appointments, among whom is Dr Kent. Two years since, Worthington was nominated by the President as Commissioner of Land-titles at St. Augustine, and negatived by the Senate— But Dr Kent thinks that the Senate would now be more favourably disposed— The Dr. told me also that he expected the whole vote of Maryland at the next Election would be for me—“Nimium ne crede colori!”— I sent and requested General Van Ness to call at my house— I told him that immediately after my last conversation with him, I had sent to Mrs Moulton who had executed a Deed to me of her furniture, which I had sent to N. York, to be confirmed by her husband— That I was expecting every day its return from New-York, and would now pay the Note— I gave him accordingly a check upon the Bank for the whole sum, desiring him to send me the note— I said I had considered the proposal which he had made me from Mr Kerr, to give me an order for the further quarter’s rent accrued since the note was given, and should not accept it, as I would not have one cent of interest in the affair on my own account— But if he would sent a receipt in full for it to Mr Moulton, or to me for her, it would be an act of Charity to her, and I would take it as an act of kindness to me. I asked him if he had enquired
of Mr Kerr, whether he had not received a second Note, from Mrs Adams?— He had; and Mr Kerr had said he believed he had; but it was altogether confirmative of the first— I said that was a mistake, and that I should be glad to have copies of both the Notes— I called at the Metropolis Bank, and left my Bank Book there to be balanced— At the Office Coll. Forbes came, and renewed his solicitations for an appointment somewhere. He said he had seen several members of the Senate; none of whom could distinctly tell him, why he was negatived upon a nomination as Marshal of East-Florida two years ago— He thought they would be better disposed now— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General came to enquire, concerning the resignation of Mr T. B. Johnson at New-Orleans— Said he had heard Mrs Adams had received a Letter from him announcing that he had resigned. I knew of no such Letter. He spoke also of the Post-Office at Providence; which will be given to Wheeler— And he was much concerned about the Presidential Election, especially for the States of New-York and Ohio— He was anxious for a concentration of opinions in New-York, and especially for the Convention at Utica— He said he had seen a Letter from Micah Sterling a member of the last Congress, and now at Albany; saying that he had seen Coll. Young, since his nomination by the Legislative Caucus, and Young had explicitly declared himself against Mr Crawford— I was at the President’s— Returned to him his draft of a Message and two Memoirs, concerning his Accounts and Claims— Left with him also the papers for and against W. F. Steele, District Attorney in West-Florida, and the papers from Mr Cheves, concerning the proceedings of the Slave-indemnity Commission— I had evening visits from Mr Hand and Mr Fowler a Clergyman from Connecticut— Attended, the Drawing Room at the President’s, and afterwards a musical party of Ladies and Gentlemen, at Mr Jackson the British Commissioner’s— Pearman and Miss Emily Monroe sang a duet, and he, several Songs— I came home as they were going in to Supper.

15. VII— Rose with a severe head ache, and bad Cold. Fuller was here to converse upon the Politics of the day— He spoke of information from various quarters that a combined and systematic effort was making in Massachusetts to secure the federalists in support of Mr Crawford— And this object is to be brought to bear upon the Elections for the House of Representatives in the present year— Fuller spoke also of the Tariff Bill which passed yesterday to the third reading by a vote of 105 to 102 in the House of Representatives. Mr Burton called while Fuller was with me, but hearing I was engaged, went away saying he would come at another Time— Pemberton, the strolling Orator and Minstrel came to ask for an answer to a Letter, which he had written yesterday to Mrs Adams, requesting her to name an Evening when she could attend, and make a party to his recitations. I told him
that the state of Mrs Adams’s health was so precarious that she could not name any day with a certainty of being able herself to attend. But observed that as he had obligingly sent me a ticket for his recitations I would with pleasure attend at the next Evening when he should give them— Wyer called to tell me that the Protest at the Metropolis Bank of the Note with my endorsement on it, had been a subject of conversation at the tavern dinner table yesterday, and to enquire into the facts— He said it was supposed to be a political contrivance of General Van Ness the President of the Bank, to injure me. G. Sullivan came in and interrupted Wyer’s Story— Sullivan shewed me two Letters, which he had received yesterday from Mr Webster, expressing a great earnestness in behalf of the Massachusetts claim— This is a sudden movement of Webster immediately on the ascertainment that W. Eustis has been re-elected Governor of Massachusetts— The federal party having failed in an agonizing effort to recover their ascendency— Sullivan spoke of his own desire to be elected a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, and seemed to solicit the aid of my influence to accomplish his election.— He told me too that Hamilton, the Chairman of the Military Committee of the House of Representatives in Congress to whom the President’s Message relating to the claim has been referred thought there would not be time for the Committee to report upon it, during the present Session— I thought it very important that the Report should be made, particularly as there was reason to expect it would be favourable— If it should pass over to the next Session there was no certainty that the Committee would be the same— An attempt had been made already, insidiously instigated by Clay the Speaker, to refer it to the Committee of Claims; which would in all probability have reported against it— At the next Session he might have it in his power to give it a direction as he pleased; which would certainly be against it. We had a further desultory Conversation upon political topics, which are now universally involved in the Presidential Election. Sullivan’s anticipations are sangwine— Mine are not— My great concern is to be prepared to meet with the proper temper of mind, the Event, and to comport myself with equanimity under it. I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and took my Book balanced. Kerr was there, and I said that I had given General Van Ness a check for the amount of Mrs Moulton’s Note, and he had promised to send me the Note itself— Kerr said that he should retain it till the charge of one dollar and seventy-five Cents for the notarial protest should be paid.— I said that the notarial protest was made in the name of the President and Directors of the Metropolis Bank, and it was to them, if to any one that I was answerable for the charge of protest, and I asked Thomas to request Genl. Van Ness to call at my house to-morrow
morning— At the Office, I was uninterrupted, and occupied chiefly in reading despatches from H. Nelson. Evening walk, and afterwards at home, writing.

16. VII:Mr Gazlay, a member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, brought five papers, authenticated by C. W. Byrd, District Judge of the U.S. for that District, and to which the Certificate of the Department of State was desired—to be used in France— He left them with me, to be returned to him— Mr Wallenstein called for a proof sheet which he had yesterday sent me of an Advertisement, written in French by him, and translated by Professor Ticknor, for publication with engravings by Stone, from Retsch, of illustrations from Goethe’s Faust— Wallenstein had asked me to revise the Translation, which I now did very hastily. I returned also his Meteorological Observations which he had sent me some weeks before— Dr. Everett, the President’s private Secretary, came to tell me that the President had determined, if I saw no objection, to nominate Mr Cook, as Marshal for the District of Missouri— I said I should be entirely satisfied with that appointment, if the President had concluded not to nominate E. Bates— Referring to what had passed at the Cabinet Meeting, I said that I retained the opinion which I had there expressed, namely, that if the charges against Rector, made by Bates under his own signature in the newspapers, were well founded, his having made them was so far from being an objection against his appointment, that I thought it his strongest recommendation— But Rector was now here— Whether he had exculpated himself or not, I did not know— Nor if the President had made up his mind not to nominate Bates, did I wish to press him further in his favour, and if Bates was not nominated, it would be altogether satisfactory to me, that Cook should be— At the Office, Mr Adlum came to enquire, if I would take any of his wines of the present year— His vineyard near Georgetown increases from year to year, but his grapes of the last year did not ripen so well as heretofore, and his wine is not so good, as that of last Summer. He is obliged to put both sugar and Brandy into all his wines; he says because his vines are not yet old enough to produce grapes, with saccharine matter and Spirit enough in them, for the preservation of their liquor— I advised him to change the names of his wines, and particularly to avoid giving them the names of such choice foreign Wines as Tokay and Champagne— He planted his first vines in the fall of 1818. and has now four acres under cultivation from which he has made the last Season 800 Gallons of wine, reduced by the failure of part of the vintage to 600 Gallons. He will call at my house in a few days, and I propose to visit his vineyard— Mr Cowper of Norfolk came and took his two Deeds— I shewed him the Deed from Coxe to A. and G. Way of 1813. with which he declared himself satisfied in regard to his enquiries.
Mr C. S. Todd late Agent to the Republic of Colombia, came with the Statement of his Accounts, together with one from the 5th. Auditor’s Office, and his vouchers; upon which I am to take the President’s directions. Mr Cazenove of Alexandria came with his Son who is going to Europe, and offered to take despatches for the Department— This Evening after a walk, I called and passed an hour in Conversation with John Taylor of Caroline, Senator from Virginia, a Chronicle of the olden time— Newton was not there— On returning home I found Mr N. Biddle, the President of the Bank of the United States, arrived this day from Philadelphia; who spent with us the remainder of the Evening.

17. VII.Charles Rich, a member of the House of Representatives from Vermont, called this morning to take leave, intending to leave the City to-morrow, to return home— He has waited only for the passage of the tariff-bill, which was carried yesterday, by a vote of 107 to 102. The largest vote ever taken in the House—two members only being absent— Mr Ingham from Pennsylvania, called home by sickness in his family, and Mr Jennings of Indiana, confined at his lodgings by illness himself— One seat being vacated—(Mr Bailey’s.) and the Speaker not voting. N. Macon, Senator and Lewis Williams a Representative from North-Carolina, came to ask a Passport, and Letters of introduction from me to Mr Rush and Mr Brown, for Joseph Caldwell, President of the University of North-Carolina, who is going to Europe, to purchase a library and apparatus for that Institution— I promised them— I called at T.
